bibl.title: Letter from Edward Champe Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, May 25, 1935

div1.p: Edward Carter encourages Laura Armistead Carter to visit Harry Leitch in New York.

div1.head: Letter from Edward Champe Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, May 25, 1935
div1.opener:
Drawer P.,
Staunton, Virginia.
May 25, 1935.
Saturday morning.
Belovedest Babbie;
div1.p:
Received your Special this morning, but had to wait to answer it
until after the routine office jobs were attended to, and then two
kids given piano and harmony lessons, and, another is waiting right now,
(a man) for voice. But I want to say, as I feel sure you already know,
how much genuine pleasure your dear letter has given me. It was what
“Harry Thomas” would call “a REAL letter”. By the way, if you and “Edward
the Second” get to New York any time, look Harry Thomas up. At present
he is living with a Hebrew in the Bronx (Mrs. A. Goldberg), at 1554
Selwyn Avenue, which is way out somewhere about 172nd Street. She has
a 'phone, but I do not know its number. Harry Thomas (Leitch) moves
periodically, however, so if you have any trouble locating him, call
Frank LaForge's secretary (Mr. Bell) at the studio at 14 West 68th Street,
and he can give latest news of the boy. The fact that Edward the Second
really knows voice would make him and Harry Thomas friends, always re-
membering that it was our late, great, old Marcella Sembrich who insisted
that Harr Thomas Leitch must become “just Harry Thomas; my Harry Thomas.”
You may not hit New York for ages, of course: but sooner or later every
body hits New York.

Outside of the angina, which is no fun, things go very well; even
the scuffle for Harry Thomas has certain compensations; it gives worth
while interest.

I am delighted about the flowers, and the details are in your hands.
I am delighted about the whole thing, for that matter.
Dear love to you, Babbie, from
div1.closer: Your devoted brother, Ned Edward C. Carter.
